subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|走|戉|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p|t1=to walk or run}} — to go over; to cross.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
[[File:CMOC Treasures of Ancient China exhibit - bronze battle axe.jpg|thumb|{{w2|zh|鉞|戉}} or {{w2|zh|鉞}}: large battle-axe used as a symbol of authority in ancient China.]]
; “to go over; to surpass; to overstep; to turn”
: Related to {{och-l|𨒋|to go over}}, {{och-l|䟠|to go beyond; to transgress}} ({{zh-ref|Wang, 1982}}) and perhaps {{och-l|于|to go}} ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

; “modal particle”
: Related to {{och-l|曰}}, {{och-l|于}} and {{och-l|粵}} ({{zh-ref|Wang, 1982}}).

; “Yue; Viet; State of Yue”
: Related to {{och-l|粵|Yue; Cantonese}}.

: This is a general name for numerous indigenous tribes in ancient southern China, which are collectively called ''{{w|Baiyue}}''. The ancient {{w|State of Yue}} during the {{w|Zhou dynasty}} of China was initially written as {{och-l|戉|large battle-axe}} — alternatively written as {{zh-l|*𫑛}} — and it is commonly believed the name ''Yue'' originates from this instrument, which was widely found in neolithic cultures of southeastern China and served as a symbol of authority and royalty.

: See {{och-l|戉}} for more on the etymology.
